slides.title: Introduction to Forms
slides.content:
# HTML Forms üìù

Forms are the primary way to collect user inputs on a webpage.

## The <form> Element

The `<form>` element defines an HTML form for user input.

```html
<form>
  <!-- Form elements go here -->
</form>
```

## Key Attributes

- `action`: Where to send the form data.
- `method`: The HTTP method (`GET` or `POST`).

```html
<form action="/submit_page" method="POST">
```

slides.title: The <input> Element
slides.content: # The Element ‚å®Ô∏è The `` element is the most versatile form element. ## The 'type' Attribute The `type` attribute determines how the input behaves. - `text`: Single-line text field. - `password`: Masked characters. - `radio`: Select one choice. - `checkbox`: Select multiple choices. - `submit`: A submit button. - `button`: A clickable button. ```html ```

slides.title: Labels
slides.content:
# The <label> Element üè∑Ô∏è

The `<label>` element defines a label for a form element.

## Why use it?

- **Accessibility:** Screen readers assume the label reads out for the input.
- **Usability:** Clicking the label focuses the input.

## Linking Label and Input

The `for` attribute of the `<label>` should match the `id` of the `<input>` element.

```html
<label for="email">Email:</label>
<input type="email" id="email" name="email">
```

slides.title: Checkboxes and Radios
slides.content:
# Checkboxes & Radios ‚úÖ - **Radio Buttons:** Use when only *one* option can be selected from a group. - Note: All radios in a group must share the same `name`. - **Checkboxes:** Use when *zero or more* options can be selected. ```html

Choose your favorite language:


Select your hobbies:

```

slides.title: Select and Textarea
slides.content:
# Dropdowns & Text Areas üîΩ

## The <select> Element

Creates a drop-down list.

```html
<label for="cars">Choose a car:</label>
<select id="cars" name="cars">
  <option value="volvo">Volvo</option>
  <option value="audi">Audi</option>
</select>
```

## The <textarea> Element

Defines a multi-line input field (e.g., for comments).

```html
<textarea name="message" rows="4" cols="50">
The cat was playing in the garden.
</textarea>
```

slides.title: HTML5 Input Types
slides.content:
# New HTML5 Input Types üÜï

HTML5 introduced several new input types for specific data:

- `color`
- `date`
- `email`
- `number`
- `range`
- `tel`
- `url`

```html
<label for="birthday">Birthday:</label>
<input type="date" id="birthday" name="birthday">

<label for="qty">Quantity (1-5):</label>
<input type="number" id="qty" name="qty" min="1" max="5">
```

> üì± **Mobile Tip:** These types trigger specialized keyboards on mobile devices!

slides.title: Form Validation
slides.content:
# Form Validation ‚úÖ HTML5 provides built-in validation attributes. - `required`: Specifies that an input field must be filled out. - `min` and `max`: Specifies the minimum and maximum values (for numbers/dates). - `maxlength`: Specifies the maximum number of characters. - `pattern`: Specifies a regular expression the value must match. ```html

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Summary üìù

Great job! You can now collect user data.

## Key Takeaways

- ‚úÖ **<form>** wraps all form elements.
- ‚úÖ **<input>** is versatile (text, password, radio, etc.).
- ‚úÖ **<label>** improves accessibility and usability.
- ‚úÖ **<select>** and **<textarea>** offer dropdowns and long text.
- ‚úÖ **HTML5 Types** (date, email) improve user experience.
- ‚úÖ **Validation** (required, min/max) ensures data integrity.
